Czes≈Çaw Koepke

Professor of physics, UMK
Faculty of Physics, Astronomy and Informatics
I am a physicist, my field of interest is solid state spectroscopy, laser physics and photonics. Currently I am involved in some activity on search for novel laser media based on transition metal or rare earths ions. Below you will find my CV and publication list, and information on my grants, our Lab and my didactics.

My specialities:

Optoelectronics

Sed at dui at mi suscipit cursus. Aenean tristique pharetra vestibulum.

Grants

  • 1988-1991

    Tunable Solid State Lasers Based on Molecular Ions

    US Army Research Office, Grant No. DAAL03-88-K-0103; Research Associate, Boston University, Boston, MA, U.S.A.

  • 1994-1996

    Fundamental Aspects of Novel Active Media for Solid State Lasers

    British-Polish Research Collaboration Programme (British Council and KBN); Co-Principal Investigator, University of Strathclyde, Glasgow, UK

  • 1994-1997

    Spectroscopy of the Higher Excited States in Solid State

    Committee for Scientific Research (KBN), Grant Nr: 2 P302 135 07; Principal Investigator, N. Copernicus University, Toru≈Ñ, Poland

  • 1999-2001

    Mixed lantanium-lutetium garnets for laser applications; growing and characterization

    Committee for Scientific Research (KBN), Grant Nr: 8 T11B 010 16; Co-Principal Investigator, Institute of Electronic Materials Technology, Warszawa, Poland

  • 1999-2002

    Changes of the charge states of transition metal and rare earth ions in dielectrics from the aspect of optoelectronic applications

    Committee for Scientific Research (KBN), Grant Nr: 2 P30B 117 16; Principal Investigator, N. Copernicus University, Toru≈Ñ, Poland

  • 2005-2008

    Diagnostics of potential laser materials based on rare earth and transition metal ions in dielectrics

    Grant of the Rector of N. Copernicus University, Grant Nr: 517-F, Principal Investigator, N. Copernicus University, Toru≈Ñ, Poland

Lab



Since 1992, together with prof. Andrzej Wojtowicz, and basing on various grants (local and external - Polish and European) we dedicate a lot of effort to create, in our modest Polish conditions, a bona fide spectroscopic laboratory. So far we have put to work several setups addressed to measurements of the following characteristics:
  • absorption spectra
  • emission spectra
  • emission decays
  • luminescence excitation spectra
  • time resolved emission spectra
  • radioluminescence spectra
  • state absorption (ESA) (and/or gain) spectra: measured in pulse regime, using a Xe-Cl excimer laser or excimer-pumped dye laser as a source of excitation, or:

  • measured in CW (or quasi-CW) regime, using an Argon ion laser as a source of excitation

  • excited state absorption decays.


A special stress is put upon the ESA measurements because they are of critical importance in determining whether a given material is a good candidate to be a laser gain medium or not.
